description: From Middle English browe, from Old English brū, from Proto-Germanic *brūwō, from Proto-Indo-European *h₃bʰrúHs (“brow”) (compare Middle Irish brúad, Tocharian B pärwāne (“eyebrows”), Lithuanian bruvìs, Serbo-Croatian obrva, Russian бровь (brovʹ), Ancient Greek ὀφρύς (ophrús), Sanskrit भ्रू (bhrū)), Persian ابرو‎ (abru, “eyebrow”)).

entries.meaning: The ridge over the eyes; the eyebrow.
examples: And his arch'd brow, pulled o'er his eyes, / With solemn proof proclaims him wise.

entries.meaning: The first tine of an antler's beam.
The projecting upper edge of a steep place such as a hill.
(mining) A gallery in a coal mine running across the face of the coal.
(nautical) The gangway from ship to shore when a ship is lying alongside a quay.
(nautical) The hinged part of a landing craft or ferry which is lowered to form a landing platform; a ramp.

verbs.description: brow (third-person singular simple present brows, present participle browing, simple past and past participle browed)

entries.meaning: To bound or limit; to be at, or form, the edge of.
